title: Think Britain is hot? Try these REALLY extreme destinations where temperatures can average 46C in the summer
text:
1

comments
Britain has been baking this week with temperatures hitting a scorching 36.7C (98.1F) in London on July 1 - the warmest day that the country has seen in 12 years.
Health officials warned Britons to stay out of the sun as the country's temperatures topped those in Athens, Barcelona and Mumbai.
But temperatures in Britain this week are put in the shade by those in the world's hottest places.
Here we take a look at the places on Earth where a sun hat and fan won't do a lot of good.
Temperatures hit a scorching 36.7C (98.1F) in London on July 1, making it the warmest day that the country has seen in 12 years. Pictured are a group of friends enjoying the hot weather at the Henley-on-Thames Regatta in Oxfordshire on Wednesday
Chennai, India
The southern Indian city regularly sees temperatures reaching 40C (or about 104F).
And on Wednesday, locals experienced temperatures of 38C (100.4F).

Share this article Share Situated along the Bay of Bengal, Chennai is the capital of the Tamil Nadu state and is home to one of the world's longest beaches..
Unfortunately, high temperatures can render the sand too hot to bear during the afternoon heat.
But in many cities around the world, such as Chennai, India, such blazing-hot temperatures are the norm
Death Valley, USA
Just yesterday, temperatures reached 37C (98.6F) in California's famed Death Valley, which is known for its parched landscape.
Located in the Mojave Desert, the Valley is the lowest, driest - and hottest - region in North America.
It also boasts the world record for the highest air temperature ever directly recorded: 56.7C or 134F.
California's Death Valley is known for its parched landscape and for having the highest air temperature ever
Death Valley is hot enough to fry an egg!...literally WORLD'S HOTTEST PLACES: Chennai, India - 38C
Death Valley, USA - 56.7C
Dallol, Ethiopia - 39C
Kebili, Tunisia - 37.8C
Ghadames, Libya - 40.6C
Las Vegas, Nevada - 47.2C
Mecca, Saudi Arabia - 42.8C
Kuwait City, Kuwait - 46.1C
Queensland Outback, Australia - 69.3C
Reports suggest the summer averages can reach anywhere between 40.6C (105F) and 46.1C (115F) during the month of July.
Interestingly, despite the heat, life can survive here and it's not uncommon to spot bobcats and bighorn sheep.
Dallol, Ethiopia
This town, in the Afar Depression of Ethiopia, is unique in having the highest average annual temperature ever recorded.
In the 1960s, Dallol averaged 34.4C (94F) year round - meaning that the temperature rarely dipped in any significant amount.
Although today Dallol, Ethiopia is uninhabited, the town operated as a mining settlement until the 1960s
Although today the area is uninhabited, it wasn't always like that. In fact, it operated as a mining settlement as recent as several decades ago.
Today, those who visit mostly do so to observe the otherworldly hydrothermal deposits and acid lakes.
And it doesn't have the nickname of Gateway to Hell for nothing - just yesterday, temperatures reached 39C (102.2F)
Kebili, Tunisia
The town of Kebili in central Tunisia is where some of the continent's highest-ever temperatures have been recorded. They often reach 37.8C (100F) in July.
Kebili, Tunisia, is a particularly picturesque desert oasis where temperatures reach 37.8C (100F) in July
The town is particularly picturesque and many tourists visit in hopes of catching a glimpse of the white Mehari camel.
There's also evidence that people have lived in the town for over 200,000 years, making it a must for history buffs.
Ghadames, Libya
With an average daily temperature of 40.6C (105F) in July, this 'pearl of the desert,' as it's known, is another must-see oasis.
The Old City is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and one of the oldest pre-Saharan cities around.
The UNESCO World Heritage Site of Ghadames, Libya, has virtually no rainfall during the year
Located in northwestern Libya, the local population only tops about 10,000 - despite its popularity as a tourist destination.
Ghadames has a hot desert climate and has virtually no rainfall during the year - the annual precipitation is just 33.1mm.
Las Vegas, Nevada
The sizzling temperatures sure haven't kept tourists from descending on this bustling city, known for its nightlife and over-the-top casinos.
Las Vegas's sizzling temperatures haven't kept tourists from descending on the bustling party city
And heading inside for a luxe air-conditioned meal and a few cocktails is undoubtedly appealing, especially during the summer months.
Sin City has been known to reach temperatures of 40.6C (105F) in July, even setting a new hottest temperature record in 2013 of 47.2C (117F).
Mecca, Saudi Arabia
Home to over a million and a half people, Mecca has long been a destination for Muslims who take on the yearly pilgrimage.
Millions visit each year to pray at the world's largest Al-Haram Mosque.
Mecca has long been a destination for Muslims on their pilgrimage, despite average temperatures of 42.8C
The city itself, however, is extremely dry with average yearly rainfall tallying just a few inches.
It's perhaps unsurprising then that the average yearly temperature is a blazing 42.8C (109F).
Kuwait City, Kuwait
In this booming metropolis, sandstorms and some of the world's hottest annual temperatures are the norm.
Kuwait City is a booming metropolis known for its high temperatures, sandstorms and modern conveniences
Thankfully, it's situated by the sea and boasts plenty of modern conveniences to help locals and tourists deal with the sweltering weather.
It's easy to get out of the heat and into some air conditioning - even when temperatures average 46.1C (115F), as they tend to in July.
Queensland Outback, Australia
Australia is the driest inhabited continent in the world with much of its interior a vast desert.
During periods of drought, land surface temperatures have reached an astonishing 69.3C in the Outback
Birdsville has been called Australia's most isolated outback town Since 90 per cent of Aussies are urban-dwellers, the Outback remains relatively uninhabited - and its scorching temperatures may be to blame.
During periods of drought, especially, land surface temperatures can reach astonishing numbers, such as 69.3C (156.7F), which was picked up by satellite measurements in 2003.
But because so few people live here, it is rather difficult to ascertain accurate temperature readings - sophisticated weather stations just don't exist here.
